intro: Mascagnia sepium var. mediterranea, commonly known as the Mediterranean moonflower, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It is a member of the Apocynaceae family and is characterized by its showy, white, night-blooming flowers. The plant typically grows as a shrub with woody stems and produces small, oval-shaped fruits that contain seeds. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or coastal areas. Due to its unique flowering habit and ornamental value, it is cultivated in some regions for horticultural purposes.
